author: Ben Riley-Smith
title: British Empire is 'gone', Angela Merkel ally says as he urges In vote ahead of EU crunch talks
text:
EU Referendum British Empire is 'gone', Angela Merkel ally says as he urges In vote ahead of EU crunch talks Michael Gahrer, MEP the German Chancellor’s CDU party, says Britain would be left outside of the 'Champions League' of nations if it leaves Europe Bottoms up to Germany's record trade surplus with Britain Photo: AFP By Ben Riley-Smith , Political Correspondent 1:48PM BST 09 Oct 2015 Follow 
The British Empire is “gone”, an ally of Angel Merkel has said as he warned the UK can only remain in the “Champions League” of nations by staying in the European Union. 
Michael Gahrer, an MEP the German Chancellor’s CDU party, upped the pressure on Ms Merkel and David Cameron by warning of the impact if Britain votes to leave the EU. 
He said Scotland could go independent and banks flee overseas if Britain exits Europe and played down the chances of Mr Cameron winning the removal of a promise for “ever closer union”. 
The comments increase the pressure on the Prime Minister ahead of a working dinner with the German Chancellor at Chequers later on today. 
An In/Out vote on Britain's EU membership will be held before the end of 2017 Photo: Alamy 
Mr Cameron is understood to see Ms Merkel as a key ally in the renegotiation of Britain’s EU membership ahead of an In/Out referendum before the end of 2017. 
The Prime Minister has reportedly briefed the German Chancellor ahead of major speeches on Europe in the past with Ms Merkel seen by many as the most important political figure in the EU. 
Speaking to BBC Radio Four’s Today Programme, Mr Gahrer said Germany felt “very strongly” that it Britain should stay in the EU and it was in both countries’ interests. 
“We are in a situation globally that we need Britain inside a union and given the ever closer threats and challenges around us we cannot construct an ever and ever looser union. I think that would not be the right answer,” he said. 
“The discussion in Britain has to address the real issues. Is there any of the major challenges and threats around us – the refugee crisis, conflict with Russia, the crisis around the Mediterranean – does anyone really think you can do it alone? That anybody of us can do it alone? I think the clear answer is no. Together we are strong.” 
Asked that many Britons will believe the country acted successful alone so for centuries, Mr Gahrer replied: “Yes, that time is gone. The Empire is gone once and for all. There is no such time anymore. 
“We are not in the Champions League alone. Together we can think of being in the Champions League globally, but not anybody of us alone.” 
Mr Gahrer also warned that an Out vote would “reopen the Scotland debate” and that the City of London’s banks “might leave if you leave”. 
He also said that Germany would not back an “ever looser union”– a warning shot over Mr Cameron’s determination to get a promise of “every closer union” removed from the EU treaties.
